intro: Rhynchostele × vexativa, commonly known as the hybrid fern, is a rare and intriguing plant that results from the cross between two different rhynchostele species. It exhibits unique morphological features, including a distinctive central vascular system that is characteristic of the rhynchostele group. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, preferring rich, organic soil conditions. Its fronds are usually bi- or tri-pinnate, with a delicate, feathery appearance that adds to its ornamental value. Due to its rarity and specific habitat requirements, it is often cultivated in specialized botanical gardens and is of interest to researchers studying hybridization in ferns.
